thread.title: Jurgen Klopp started five teenagers against Plymouth - we assess their performances
thread.title_full: Jurgen Klopp started five teenagers against Plymouth - we assess their performances

author: mirror
title: Jurgen Klopp started five teenagers against Plymouth - we assess their performances
text:
Liverpool manager Juergen Klopp shouts instructions to his team (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Share Get Liverpool FC   Thank you for subscribing!   
League Two Plymouth ground out a goalless draw at Anfield as the youngest team in Liverpool's history discovered they still have plenty to learn. 
A Reds team containing five academy graduates came up against a green wall as Argyle manager Derek Adams succeeded in making life as difficult as possible for the hosts in their FA Cup third-round encounter. 
The tactics were understandable for a side second in League Two coming to a club second in the Premier League who score for fun at home, and Plymouth now have a chance of causing an upset at Home Park. 
Here, we analyse the performances of the five teenagers that started at Anfield... TRENT ALEXANDER-ARNOLD Trent Alexander-Arnold (L) and Kevin Stewart (C) attempt to tackle Arnold Garita (Photo: Michael Steele) 
The 18-year-old earned rave reviews for his performance against Leeds in the EFL Cup earlier this season and the right-back did well again here. Composed in defence and a threat going forward, particularly in the first half. Read More OVIE EJARIA Ovie Ejaria shoots wide (Photo: Andrew Powell) 
Making his sixth appearance this season, 19-year-old Ejaria showed some nice touches in midfield but struggled to make much of an impact against the massed ranks of Plymouth defenders and was substituted. Read More SHEYI OJO Liverpool's Sheyi Ojo and Plymouth Argyle's David Fox battle for the bal (Photo: PA) 
Ojo was unfortunate to pick up a stress fracture in his back in pre-season having established himself in Klopp's first-team plans last campaign. The winger looked understandably a little rusty and should have done better with two of Liverpool's better chances. Read More BEN WOODBURN Liverpool's Ben Woodburn shoots at goal (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
This was the 17-year-old winger's first appearance since his goal-scoring breakthrough against Leeds drew him to the attention of the football world. His quick feet were again on show, and he forced Plymouth keeper Luke McCormick into a decent save with one slaloming run. Woodburn made less of an impact in the second half and was taken off with 15 minutes left. Like us on Facebook
